question_text: Has the establishment determined its coverage under the Act based on employing five or more persons on any working day during the preceding twelve months?
applicability_criteria: Establishments within the meaning of the Bombay Shops and Establishments Act, 1948
simplified_guidance:
1. Review attendance registers for the preceding 12 months.
2. Identify the maximum number of persons employed on any single day.
3. If the count reached 5 or more, the Act is applicable.
4. Note that once covered, the Act continues to apply even if numbers drop.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Attendance Register or Muster Roll showing employment count; Shop Act License

legal_text: any establishment within the meaning of the Bombay Shops and Establishments Act, 1948 (Bom. LXXIX of 1948), which employs, or on any working day during the preceding twelve months, employed five or more persons including the establishments which have been granted exemption partly or wholly under the proviso to section 4 of that Act

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the establishment continue to maintain compliance with the Act even if the number of employees has temporarily reduced to less than five?
applicability_criteria: Establishments previously covered under the Act where employee count has dropped below five
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify if the establishment was previously covered under the Act.
2. Check current employee count.
3. Ensure contributions are still being deducted and paid even if current count is < 5.
4. Confirm that compliance has not been stopped without formal cessation procedures.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Proof of continued contribution payments (Challans/Receipts) during low employment periods

legal_text: Provided that, any such establishment shall continue to be an establishment for the purposes of this Act, notwithstanding a reduction in the number of persons to less than five at any subsequent time

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: If the employee count has remained below five for three continuous months, has the employer sent a registered post intimation to the authority to officially cease applicability?
applicability_criteria: Establishments seeking to exit Act coverage due to low employment
simplified_guidance:
1. Confirm employee count has been < 5 for 3 consecutive months.
2. Verify that an intimation letter was drafted.
3. Ensure the letter was sent by Registered Post within one month of the 3-month period expiring.
4. Retain the postal receipt as proof of cessation.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Copy of cessation letter and Registered Post receipt
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: None (Compliance ceases only upon valid notice)

legal_text: Provided further that, where for a continuous period of not less than three months, the number of persons employed therein has been less than five such establishments shall cease to be an establishment for the purposes of this Act... but the employer shall within one month from the date of such cessation, intimate by registered post the fact thereof to such authority as the State Government may specify in this behalf

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are all branches or departments of the establishment treated as parts of the same single establishment for the purpose of coverage and compliance?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with multiple branches or departments
simplified_guidance:
1. List all branches and departments, even if at different addresses.
2. Aggregate the employee count across all locations.
3. Ensure the entity is registered as a single establishment or that all branches comply uniformly.
4. Verify that branches are not artificially split to avoid the 5-employee threshold.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Consolidated employee register; Organization chart showing branch structure
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Correspondence with head office regarding branch compliance

legal_text: Explanation. For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that where an establishment has different branches or departments, all such branches or departments, whether situated in the same premises or different premises, shall be treated as parts of the same establishment

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Has the establishment correctly classified eligible employees by excluding only those in managerial capacities or supervisors drawing wages exceeding ₹3,500 per month?
applicability_criteria: All establishments covered under the Act
simplified_guidance:
1. Review the list of excluded employees.
2. Verify that excluded supervisors earn > ₹3,500/month.
3. Verify that other excluded staff are strictly 'managerial' in function.
4. Ensure all other skilled, unskilled, manual, clerical, and technical staff are included.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Payroll records; Job descriptions of excluded staff; Salary slips of supervisors

legal_text: Employee means any person who is employed for hire or reward to do any work... but does not include any person (i) who is employed mainly in a managerial capacity, (ii) who, being employed in a supervisory capacity, draws wages exceeding three thousand and five hundred rupees per mensem, or exercises powers... mainly of a managerial nature, or (iii) who is employed as an apprentice

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the establishment calculate contributions for every employee whose name appears on the register as of 30th June and 31st December respectively?
applicability_criteria: All establishments covered under the Act
simplified_guidance:
1. Review the employee register/muster roll for 30th June and 31st December.
2. Identify all employees on the roll, regardless of whether they were present or absent on that specific day.
3. Ensure the contribution (currently ₹25) is assessed for every listed name.
4. Do not exclude employees on leave if their names are still on the register.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Muster Roll for June and December; Contribution Calculation Sheet
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Reconciliation of employee count vs contribution paid

legal_text: The amount of contribution payable every six months in respect of every employee... whose name appears in the register of an establishment on the 30th June and 31st December, respectively, shall be at the rate of twenty-five rupees

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are employee contributions deducted strictly from the wages of June and December only?
applicability_criteria: All establishments making deductions
simplified_guidance:
1. Check payroll records for June and December.
2. Verify that the deduction appears in these specific months.
3. Check payrolls for other months (e.g., July, January) to ensure no unauthorized welfare deductions are made.
4. Ensure the deduction does not exceed the prescribed employee rate.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Wage Register/Salary Slips for June and December

legal_text: Provided that, no such deduction shall be made in excess of the amount of the contribution payable by such employee, nor shall it be made from any wages other than the wages for the months of June and December

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the employer contribute an amount equal to three times the employee's contribution for each eligible employee?
applicability_criteria: All employers covered under the Act
simplified_guidance:
1. Calculate the total employee share (e.g., Number of employees × ₹25).
2. Calculate the mandatory employer share (Number of employees × ₹75).
3. Verify that the total remittance equals the sum of both shares.
4. Ensure the employer is not paying less than the 1:3 ratio.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Challan/Receipt showing total amount paid; Calculation worksheet

legal_text: in respect of an employer, for each employee referred to in clause (a), thrice the amount of contribution payable by an employee.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are the total contributions (employer + employee share) remitted to the Board before the 15th of July and 15th of January respectively?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify the due date: 15th July for June period, 15th Jan for Dec period.
2. Check the date on the payment receipt or bank challan.
3. If paid after the 15th, verify if penal interest has been calculated.
4. Ensure payment covers the full liability for that six-month period.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank Challan/Online Payment Receipt with date stamp
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Proof of payment of penal interest for late remittance

legal_text: Every employer shall pay to the Board both the employer's contribution and the employee's contribution in accordance with the provisions of sub-section (2) before the 15th day of July and 15th day of January, as the case may be.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Is the employer's share of the contribution paid directly by the employer without recovering it from the employee's wages?
applicability_criteria: All employers
simplified_guidance:
1. Audit payroll deductions for June and December.
2. Ensure the deduction amount matches exactly the employee share (e.g., ₹25).
3. If the deduction is higher (e.g., ₹100), investigate if the employer is illegally recovering their share.
4. Verify compliance with the contract of employment regarding deductions.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Salary slips; Payroll Register

legal_text: Notwithstanding any contract to the contrary, no employer shall deduct the employer's contribution from any wages payable to an employee or otherwise recover it from the employee.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: If a deduction was missed in June or December, was written permission obtained from the Inspector before deducting it in a subsequent month?
applicability_criteria: Cases where the employer failed to deduct contributions in the designated month
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify any deductions made in months other than June or December.
2. If found, request the written permission letter from the Inspector.
3. Verify the date of permission vs date of deduction.
4. Without permission, subsequent deductions are unauthorized.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Written permission letter from the Labour Welfare Inspector

legal_text: Provided further that, if through inadvertence or otherwise, no deduction has been made from the wages of an employee for the months aforesaid, such deduction may be made from the wages of such employee for any subsequent month or months with the permission in writing of the Inspector appointed under this Act.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are the employer's and employees' contributions remitted to the Board using the authorized modes of payment?
applicability_criteria: All establishments remitting contributions
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify the mode of payment used for the last remittance.
2. Ensure it was paid by Cheque, Money-order, or Cash.
3. Retain the counterfoil, receipt, or bank acknowledgement as proof.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Bank Challan; Cheque Stubs; Money Order Receipts

legal_text: An employer shall pay the employer's and the employee's contribution to the Board by cheque, money-order or in cash

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the employer bear the full expense of remitting contributions to the Board?
applicability_criteria: All establishments remitting contributions
simplified_guidance:
1. Review accounting vouchers for remittance expenses (e.g., Money Order fees, Bank Charges).
2. Ensure these costs are booked to the employer's account.
3. Verify that no part of the remittance cost is recovered from employees.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Accounting Vouchers; Expense Reports

legal_text: and he shall bear the expenses of remitting to the Board such contributions.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are all unpaid accumulations (wages or gratuity due for over three years) transferred to the Board?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with unpaid employee dues older than 3 years
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify 'unpaid accumulations' (payments due but not made within 3 years).
2. Exclude Provident Fund contributions.
3. Transfer these amounts to the Board at prescribed intervals.
4. Maintain a separate account until claims are decided.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Ledger of Unpaid Accumulations; Proof of Transfer to Board

legal_text: notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract or instrument, all unpaid accumulations shall be paid at such intervals as may be prescribed to the Board, which shall keep a separate account therefor

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are all fines realized from employees remitted to the Fund?
applicability_criteria: Establishments where fines are imposed on employees
simplified_guidance:
1. Check the Register of Fines.
2. Calculate the total fines realized during the period.
3. Verify that the full amount has been transferred to the Labour Welfare Fund.
4. Ensure no fines are retained by the employer.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Fines Register; Payment Receipt/Challan

legal_text: The Fund shall consist of... all fines realised from the employees

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: If a notice of demand for unpaid dues is served by the Welfare Commissioner, is payment made within the specified period?
applicability_criteria: Employers receiving a specific demand notice for default
simplified_guidance:
1. Check incoming correspondence for Demand Notices from the Welfare Commissioner.
2. Verify the deadline specified in the notice (minimum 30 days).
3. Ensure payment is made strictly within this period.
4. Retain proof of payment against the notice.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Demand Notice; Proof of Payment
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Appeal or representation against the notice

legal_text: the Welfare Commissioner may cause to be served a notice on such employer to pay the amount within the period specified therein which shall not be less than thirty days from the date of service of such notice.

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Has the employer paid the applicable penal interest for any contributions not paid by the 15th of July or January?
applicability_criteria: Employers who have delayed contribution payments
simplified_guidance:
1. Identify late payments (paid after 15th July/Jan).
2. Calculate interest: 1.5% per month for the first 3 months.
3. Calculate interest: 2% per month for subsequent months.
4. Verify that this interest amount was added to the remittance.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Interest Calculation Sheet; Challan showing interest component
evidence_requirements.delay_proof: Application for remission of penalty (if applicable)

legal_text: pay to the Board simple interest... (i) for the first three months, at one and a half percent. of the said amount for each completed month... (ii) thereafter, at two per cent. of that amount for each completed month

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Has the employer identified and paid all 'unpaid accumulations' (wages/gratuity due for over 3 years) to the Welfare Board?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with wages or gratuity remaining unpaid for more than 3 years
simplified_guidance:
1. Review the Register of Unpaid Wages/Wages Register.
2. Identify payments that became due more than 3 years ago but were not paid.
3. Verify that these specific amounts have been transferred to the Board.
4. Ensure payment is made notwithstanding other laws like Payment of Wages Act.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Proof of transfer (Challan/Receipt); Register of Unpaid Accumulations

legal_text: notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract or instrument, all unpaid accumulations shall be paid at such intervals as may be prescribed to the Board

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are all fines realized from employees during the period transferred to the Labour Welfare Fund?
applicability_criteria: Establishments that impose fines on employees
simplified_guidance:
1. Check the 'Register of Fines' maintained under Factories Act or Shops Act.
2. Sum up the total fines realized in the accounting period.
3. Verify the remittance challan to the Board covers this exact amount.
4. Ensure fines are not used for other internal welfare activities unless authorized.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Register of Fines; Bank Challan showing transfer to LWF

legal_text: The Fund shall consist of... all fines realised from the employees

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: If unpaid accumulations or fines were paid late, has the employer paid the mandatory penal interest?
applicability_criteria: Employers who defaulted on timely payment of unpaid accumulations or fines
simplified_guidance:
1. Determine the due date for the payment of unpaid accumulations/fines.
2. Calculate the delay period.
3. Apply interest: 1.5% per month for the first 3 months.
4. Apply interest: 2% per month for months thereafter.
5. Verify proof of interest payment.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Interest calculation sheet; Payment receipt

legal_text: in the case of failure to pay any amount of unpaid accumulations or fines realised from the employees... (i) for the first three months, at one and a half per cent. of the said amount... (ii) thereafter, at two per cent. of that amount

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the establishment maintain a separate account for unpaid accumulations until they are transferred to the Board?
applicability_criteria: All establishments with unpaid accumulations
simplified_guidance:
1. Verify the chart of accounts or ledger.
2. Ensure a specific liability account exists for 'Unpaid Accumulations'.
3. Confirm that funds are not commingled with general working capital in a way that prevents tracing.
4. This account helps track the 3-year aging for transfer.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Accounting Ledger; Balance Sheet Schedule

legal_text: Board, which shall keep a separate account therefor until claims thereto have been decided in the manner provided in section 6A

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the employer retain records of payments made to the Board to act as a valid discharge of liability towards employees?
applicability_criteria: All employers transferring funds to the Board
simplified_guidance:
1. Retain the receipt/acknowledgment from the Board for all transfers of unpaid accumulations.
2. If an employee claims these old dues later, use this receipt to prove liability was transferred.
3. Note: The discharge of liability is only to the extent of the amount paid.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Board Receipts; Transfer Challans

legal_text: Any unpaid accumulations paid to the Board in accordance with the provision of section 3 shall on such payment, discharge an employer of the liability to make payment to an employee in respect thereof, but to the extent only of the amount paid to the Board

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the establishment ensure that Inspectors are not obstructed in the exercise of their powers or discharge of duties?
applicability_criteria: All establishments subject to inspection
simplified_guidance:
1. Ensure security staff are aware of Inspector entry rights.
2. Allow Inspectors to enter premises at any reasonable time.
3. Do not delay or refuse entry to authorized officers.
4. Cooperate during the physical verification of staff or premises.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Inspection Book/Visit Remarks

legal_text: Any person who wilfully obstruct an Inspector in the exercise of his powers or discharge of his duties under this Act... shall, on conviction, be punished

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Are all registers, records, and documents maintained under the Act produced immediately upon demand by the Inspector?
applicability_criteria: All establishments maintaining records
simplified_guidance:
1. Keep MLWF records (registers, challans, notices) readily accessible.
2. Produce them immediately when requested by an Inspector.
3. Ensure that the absence of a senior manager does not prevent record production.
4. Failure to produce documents is a specific punishable offence.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Acknowledgement of produced records in Inspection Report

legal_text: or fails to produce for inspection on demand by an Inspector any registers, records or other documents maintained in pursuance of the provisions of this Act or the rules made thereunder

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the employer supply true copies of any documents demanded by the Inspector?
applicability_criteria: All establishments
simplified_guidance:
1. If an Inspector requests copies of registers or challans, provide them.
2. Certify them as 'True Copies' if required.
3. Ensure the copies are legible and complete.
4. Submit them within the timeline specified by the Inspector.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Cover letter submitting documents; Receipt from Inspector

legal_text: or to supply to him on demand true copies of any such documents shall, on conviction, be punished

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Does the establishment recognize and cooperate with Shop Act Inspectors acting as Inspectors for the Labour Welfare Fund?
applicability_criteria: Establishments covered under Bombay Shops and Establishments Act
simplified_guidance:
1. Note that Inspectors appointed under the Bombay Shops and Establishments Act are deemed Inspectors for MLWF.
2. Do not deny them access on the grounds that they are not from the Welfare Board.
3. Their jurisdiction for MLWF is the same as their Shop Act area.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Security Protocol; Management Awareness

legal_text: Inspectors appointed, whether by a local authority or the State Government under the Bombay Shops and Establishments Act, 1948... shall be deemed to be also Inspectors for the purposes of this Act

meta_data.source_act: The Maharashtra Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953

question_text: Is the management aware that for second or subsequent offences involving obstruction or failure to produce records, the fine cannot be less than fifty rupees?
applicability_criteria: Establishments with prior convictions under the Act
simplified_guidance:
1. Review history of non-compliance.
2. Note that for repeat offences, the court has mandatory minimum fine instructions.
3. Ensure strict compliance to avoid triggering 'subsequent offence' clauses.

evidence_requirements.compliance_proof: Legal Register updating penalty clauses

legal_text: Provided that, in the absence of special and adequate reasons to the contrary to be mentioned in the judgement of the Court, in any case where the offender is sentenced to a fine only, the amount of fine shall not be less than fifty rupees.
